awd_titl_txt: Conference: Travel Support for the 9th Thermal and Fluids Engineering Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF support will enable numerous students, early career engineers, and faculty members around the country to attend the 9th Thermal and Fluids Engineering Conference (TFEC), thereby leading to their significant intellectual benefit and professional development. The TFEC, organized by the American Society of Thermal and Fluids Engineers (ASTFE), is growing to be one of the leading platforms for presenting and discussing research advances in thermal and fluids engineering. Since its inception in 2015, TFEC has been organized in a progressively student-centric fashion by seeking firsthand input from the student attendees. In line with the students' top priority, the 9th TFEC will invite 14 plenary, keynote, and special talk speakers and facilitate their interaction with the students. This support will also enable the students to realize their second priority: networking and socialization.

The field of thermal and fluids engineering impacts a vast spectrum of our industry and society. New advances in this field prompted by the attendance and collaborations at the conference through this support would help improve and optimize numerous applications of societal benefit such as gas and wind turbines, fuel cells, electric vehicles, electronic devices, freshwater production, power plants, industrial processes, and medicine among others. In addition, programming at the conference will aid in enhancing the professional development and career selection skills of both the current and the future workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Forty-nine thousand nine-hundred and eight dollars were obtained to support travel and registration costs for the 9th Thermal and Fluids Engineering Conference (TFEC), organized by the American Society of Thermal and Fluids Engineers (ASTFE).  These funds supported travel and registration costs for 50 US-based students, postdoctoral fellows, faculty members, and leaders from industry.  The conference was hosted by Oregon State University in April of 2024. The TEFC has been an annual conference since 2015 and has grown to become one of the leading platforms for presenting and discussing research advances in thermal and fluids engineering. Although primarily a US-based conference, there is significant international participation at TFEC, resulting in a broad dissemination of research.

A noteworthy aspect of the conference was been the student- and early career-centric approach to organizing the conference. Financial support provided by NSF has played a notable role in this regard. Many students who could not have attended the conference without the travel support from NSF have greatly benefited from the professional exposure and networking opportunities this support has created for them.

A key feature of the conference was the focus on broadening the exposure of students and early career engineers to technical topics of interest.  For example, the conference included 3 distinguished plenary speakers (e.g., leaders from Intel, NuScale, MIT), 7 invited talks (including fields of wildfires, nuclear power, HVAC, and heat transfer), and 3 technology talks.  The invited talks include several distinguished women engineers

Intellectual Merit

The proposed NSF support enabled numerous students, early career engineers, and faculty members across the country to attend the 9th TFEC, thereby leading to their significant intellectual benefit and professional development. The participation of invited speakers and panelists directly encouraged by the support enhanced and broadened the conference's technical content, benefitting all the attendees. This travel grant aided the conference's goal of facilitating research in multiple directions related to heat transfer and fluids engineering. The increased number of attendees sponsored through this grant will likely lead to exciting and fruitful technical conversations and new research collaborations for addressing pressing fundamental and applied thermal and fluids engineering problems.

 Broader Impacts

The field of thermal and fluids engineering impacts a vast spectrum of our industry and society in general. New advances in this field prompted by attendance and collaborations at the conference as a result of this grant should help improve and optimize numerous applications of societal benefit such as gas and wind turbines, fuel cells, electric vehicles, electronic devices, freshwater production, power plants, industrial processes, and medicine among others.

Begell House publishes all the accepted full papers and extended abstracts at the TFEC in the form of archival conference proceedings. This paper set is compiled and made available on the Begell House website which will result in a broad dissemination of research results presented at the conference.

Given that the conference is being held in Oregon, selected keynote/plenary talks and other activities were specifically planned to introduce the audience to local developments and entrepreneurial efforts and success stories of relevance to thermal/fluids engineering.  Conference organizers strove to ensure a diverse representation of travel grant beneficiaries.

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2025
Modified by: David L Blunck
